moves.1. e3 e5: Amsterdam Attack. The main line continues 2. c4 d6 3. Nc3 Nc6 4. b3 Nf6.
moves.2. Nc3 Nf6 3. Nge2 d5: An ambitious move on my part that may prove a liability later on.
moves.4. d4: Solid response - establishes a pawn presence in the centre and threatens to win a pawn with dxe5.
moves.4... Bd6: Also possible was 4... e4, but this is open to attack after 5 f3.
moves.8... O-O 9. e4: A dubious move by white, as my next move shows, regaining a pawn.
moves.9... Nxe4 10. Bd3 Nd6 11. O-O: At this stage, I probably had a slight edge, with my bishop pair a more powerful force than white's bishops. However, the game could still easily have gone either way.
moves.11... Nd4 12. Bxf5 Nd6xf5 13. Re1 Re8: Reluctant to allow white control of the e-file.
moves.20. Ra2: Rab1 would have forced the b-file semi-open but losing another pawn on a3.
moves.20... Bf6 21. Kf1 b5 22. Ng3 Rxe1+: Swapping off material to try and enter an advantageous endgame.
moves.23. Kxe1 Nxg3 24. Bxg3 a5 25. Bd6 Bc3+ 2: A blunder. Underestimates the power of the pin on d8.
moves.26... Rd8: The white bishop is now lost, and I was free to take it at any time.
moves.27. a4 b4: 27... bxa4 28 Rxa4 and the white rook is freed. This keeps the white rook in isolation for a while yet.
moves.28. Kc1 Rxd6: White abandoned the bishop to its fate, so I took it.
moves.29. Rb2: ?? To me, this seems to be a blunder. By exchanging bishop for rook, I was able to take a massive lead over white. His only advantage over me at this point was a more active king, but only marginally so - the d-file is blocked and my pawns block a3, c3 and b5.
moves.29... Bxb2+ 30. Kxb2 f5 31. f4 Kf7: I considered Rd4 to stop the white king coming out via c4 but this is weak to 32 c3 bxc3  33 Kxc3. (32... other move 33 cxb4 axb4 and I have to stop white's a-pawn, a headache I didn't need.)
moves.32. Kb3: Aiming for c4, as I feared.
moves.32... Ke6: Now Kc4 can be met by 33... Rd5 and the white king is kept away from a5. More importantly, I can use my better placed king and rook to mop up white's king-side pawns.
moves.33. Kc4 Rd5 34. g3 h5 35. Kb3 Rc5: c3 can be met by bxc3, and c4 by bxc3 e.p.
moves.36. c3 bxc3 37. Kc2 g6 38. h4: At this point, white resigned. Although he had managed to free his king, moving it would let me promote my c-pawn, with victory sure to follow. Thank you for reading this. Comments are welcome.
